FY2021.Q31: The mission of the New York State Mesonet (NYSM) is to serve the state of New York by providing the best meteorological data, the best products, and the best services possible with the goal of saving lives and property while building a smart weather economy. At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. With its unique focus on research to operations, preventive maintenance, and state-of-the-art quality control efforts, the NYSM utilizes these high quality weather data to create end products designed to improve forecast accuracy, reduce uncertainty, and mitigate harm.
FY2021.Q32: The vision of the New York State Mesonet is to become a national center, collaborating with government, academic, and commercial partners, to educate and solve real-world problems in agriculture, emergency management, energy, public health, and transportation, improving the well being and livelihood for all.
FY2021.Q41:
Approximately $1M.  Actual need is ~ $2.5M.
Money received is a mix of federal money from the National Mesonet Program (via private contractor), direct funds from research grants, and university support.
FY2021.Q62: 1. J. Brotzge, J. Wang, C. Thorncroft, E. Joseph, N. Bain, N. Bassill, N. Farruggio, J. Freedman, K. Hemker, D. Johnston, E. Kane, S. McKim, S. Miller, J. Minder, P. Naples, S. Perez, J. J. Schwab, M. J. Schwab, and J. Sicker, 2020: A Technical Overview of the New York State Mesonet Standard Network, J. Atmos. Oceanic Technol., 1-48.
FY2021.Q81_4: Design and deployment of a $1M, 17-station urban network across New York City for Consolidated Edison, Inc.  These data are used for monitoring climate and for use in short-term utility operations.
FY2021.Q81_5: Design and deployment of a 12-station solar measurement network across the Hudson River Valley in collaboration with NYSERDA and regional utilities.  These data will be used to optimize data usage by utilities for integration of renewable solar energy production.
FY2021.Q81_6: Operate and maintain 180+ station New York State Mesonet with an uptime of > 99%. During 2020-2021, the NYSM has incorporated its own Calibration Laboratory, which is now fully functional.
FY2021.Q81_7: Secured $400K in federal funding for the NYSM National Profiler Network for the 2020-2021 fiscal year.  The NYSM is establishing a national testbed for the development, testing, and evaluation of ground-based vertical profiling technologies.
FY2021.Q81_8: The NYSM, in collaboration with university and external partners, submitted 14 proposals during the 2020-2021 fiscal year. These were submitted to NSF, NASA, NIH, DOE, and NOAA.
FY2021.Q91: Operate and maintain all 222 statewide weather stations of the NYS Mesonet during 2020 - 2021 with a combined 97.5%+ uptime.
FY2021.Q92: The above goal was accomplished.  The NYSM continues to maintain its 180 stations, plus additional collaborative networks, including the 12-station roadside network, 12-station solar network, 17-station urban network, and 1 DOT wind site. The NYSM achieved 99%+ uptime during the year period.
FY2021.Q93: The NYSM achieved 99% uptime during the year.
FY2021.Q94: The NYSM achieved 99%+ uptime during the 01/01/20 - 12/31/20 period.  The NYSM has continued to record 99%+ during 2021.
FY2021.Q95: To continue to achieve this level of performance, the NYSM has developed its own Calibration Laboratory.  This new Cal Lab allows the NYSM to calibrate its own sensors, providing a more cost-effective and faster turnaround on sensor calibrations and repairs.
FY2021.Q101: To lead and support grant sponsored research of at least $1 million during the 2020-2021 season.
FY2021.Q102: Achieved.  The NYSM realized > $1M in external project research.  Specifically, the NYSM collaborated with Consolidated Edison, Inc. to design and deploy a 17-station urban weather network across NYC.
FY2021.Q103: The NYSM achieved > $1M in external projects.
FY2021.Q104: The NYSM achieved > $1M in external projects between June 2020 and present.
FY2021.Q111: Expand NYS Mesonet communications through increased peer-reviewed publications and media.
FY2021.Q112: The NYSM completed its first overview paper with publication of a description of its network in a peer-reviewed journal.  Additional papers were submitted for review.
FY2021.Q113: The NYSM completed its first journal publication, with 3 additional papers written and either submitted for review or are ready for submission.
FY2021.Q114: The papers were published and/or submitted for review since June 2020.
FY2021.Q115: Set aside time for publication of results.  Continue to write and submit additional papers for publication.
FY2021.Q151: NYSM is leading the development of a national Profiling Testbed, and associated with that, is a co-PI on two large nationally-led proposals.  Many opportunities to expand collaborations across the transportation, health, agriculture, and energy sectors.
FY2021.Q152: The NYSM requires publicly funded financial support, and so far, has received no support from NYS.  The NYSM supports many state agencies, and so the lack of financial support from the state has severely limited what NYSM has been able to accomplish.
FY2021.Q153: The NYSM has operated on a budget of ~ $1M, but requires an annual budget of ~$2.5M.  The NYSM needs several additional staff in order to expand its collaborations with external partners.
FY2021.Q154: The NYSM has weather operations in every county and borough across New York State.  Local political leaders could be approached to support those operations within their districts.  Furthermore, data generated from these stations can be made available to local schools, if support could be obtained to do so.
FY2021.FY2021Mission: The mission of the New York State Mesonet (NYSM) is to serve the state of New York by providing the best meteorological data, the best products, and the best services possible with the goal of saving lives and property while building a smart weather economy. At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. With its unique focus on research to operations, preventive maintenance, and state-of-the-art quality control efforts, the NYSM utilizes these high quality weather data to create end products designed to improve forecast accuracy, reduce uncertainty, and mitigate harm.
FY2021.FY2021Vision: The vision of the New York State Mesonet is to become a national center, collaborating with government, academic, and commercial partners, to educate and solve real-world problems in agriculture, emergency management, energy, public health, and transportation, improving the well being and livelihood for all.
FY2021.FY2021Goal1: 1. Operate and maintain all 222 statewide weather stations of the NYS Mesonet during 2020 - 2021 with a combined 97.5%+ uptime.
FY2021.FY2021Action1:
(a) Continued improvement in data quality control software.
(b) Continued training of field staff.
(c) Continued sensor rotation of aging sensors and equipment.
FY2021.FY2021Metric1: All data are archived and daily statistics are compiled to record the percentage of all data received in real-time.  We have a detailed record of all station uptime percentages for all periods.
FY2021.FY2021Goal2: To lead and support grant sponsored research of at least $1 million during the 2020-2021 season.
FY2021.FY2021Action2:
(a) Lead the writing of several proposals to federal and state RFPs.
(b) Aid UAlbany and external NYS Mesonet partners in support of their proposals.  
(c) Expand and deepen ongoing collaborations.
FY2021.FY2021Metric2:
(a) Track the number of proposals submitted from the NYS Mesonet.
(b) Track the amount of grant funding from federal, state, and other sources.
(c) Track the number of proposals including NYS Mesonet funding.
FY2021.FY2021Goal3: Expand NYS Mesonet communications through increased peer-reviewed publications and media.
FY2021.FY2021Action3:
(a) Make peer-reviewed journal writing a specific focus for some research activities. 
(b) Expand web/Facebook/Twitter presence.
(c) Expand media opportunities for the Mesonet.
FY2021.FY2021Metric3:
1. Track the number of journal articles submitted for peer review.
2. Track the number of formal publications referencing Mesonet.
3. Track the number of followers on Facebook/Twitter/web.
4. Track the number and frequency of media stories following Mesonet.

FY2122.Q31: The mission of the New York State Mesonet (NYSM) is to serve the state of New York by providing the best meteorological data, the best products, and the best services possible with the goal of saving lives and property while building a smart weather economy. At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. With its unique focus on research to operations, preventive maintenance, and state-of-the-art quality control efforts, the NYSM utilizes these high quality weather data to create end products designed to improve forecast accuracy, reduce uncertainty, and mitigate harm.
FY2122.Q32: The vision of the New York State Mesonet is to become a national center, collaborating with government, academic, and commercial partners, to educate and solve real-world problems in agriculture, emergency management, energy, public health, and transportation, improving the well being and livelihood for all.
FY2122.Q41: Annual budget projection is approximately $1.5 million. Salary is estimated at about $1.1 million, and equipment and miscellaneous expenses are estimated at $400,000.
FY2122.Q71: Operate and maintain all 222 statewide weather stations of the NYS Mesonet during 2020 - 2021 with a combined 97.5%+ uptime.
FY2122.Q72:
Activities include:
- Maintain well-trained and experienced staff.
- Maintain trucks and support equipment.
- Pro-actively maintain sensors (well calibrated)
FY2122.Q73: We will use our network and site uptimes to document how well we have maintained the network.  Our goal is 99% uptime; we are expected to maintain at least a 95% uptime rate.
FY2122.Q74: We will assess this goal in May 2022.
FY2122.Q76: Significant changes to staff and/or funding could impact the network uptime and speed at which sensors are repaired/replaced.
FY2122.Q77: DAES and ASRC staff; Sponsored Programs Administration
FY2122.Q78: The NYS Mesonet provides a foundation of high-quality observations to support university research excellence.  The Mesonet is uniquely designed to support cutting-edge research; the NYS Mesonet is the only statewide observing system to support networks of cameras, vertical profiling systems, snow water equivalent sensors, and surface energy budget sensors.  Data from the Mesonet has already supported research in emergency management, renewable energy, transportation, education and health, with many more applications to come.
FY2122.Q81: To lead and support grant sponsored research of at least $1 million during the 2020-2021 season.
FY2122.Q82:
Continued internal collaborations (e.g., ASRC, DAES, COE, School of Public Health, and others) and external partnerships (e.g., Consolidated Edison, Inc., Syracuse University, Cornell University, CUNY, and others).
Expanded education and outreach.
FY2122.Q83: We will track and monitor the total amount of new and ongoing grant dollars received.
FY2122.Q86: Changes in staff and/or changes in financial support to the center.
FY2122.Q87: DAES, ASRC, and Sponsored Programs Administration.
FY2122.Q88: The Mesonet's focus on building a research portfolio supports the university's goal to "Identify and support innovative research opportunities..."  We have collaborated in over 20 proposals since the Mesonet was started five years ago, and continue to build and strengthen these partnerships.
FY2122.Q91: Expand NYS Mesonet communications through increased peer-reviewed publications and media.
FY2122.Q92: Focused time for writing, publishing, and advertising our operational and research programs and results.
FY2122.Q93: We continue to track our internal publications and external publications that utilize Mesonet data.
FY2122.Q96: Changes to our staff and/or changes to the financial support of the center.
FY2122.Q98: Publication of results provides university staff and faculty with new opportunities for broadening external engagement and innovate research collaborations.
FY2122.Q101: Expand NYS Mesonet educational outreach to at least 20 institutional partners.
FY2122.Q102: Continued partnership with the UAlbany School of Education; proposal submission, and engagement with the Master Teach program.
FY2122.Q103: We will monitor and track the number of engaged K-12 partners utilizing NYS Mesonet data and integrating it into school curriculum.
FY2122.Q106: Changes to NYS Mesonet staff and/or changes to financial support of the program.
FY2122.Q107: School of Education, Master Teachers Program.
FY2122.Q108: Engagement with K-12 schools provides excellent innovative outreach and research opportunities.
FY2122.Q111: Formal, collaborative partnerships with 20+ external organizations that either pay for Mesonet data and/or collaborating with the NYS Mesonet on research activities.
FY2122.Q113: The number of formal collaborative partners will be regularly monitored.
FY2122.Q116: Changes in NYS Mesonet staff and/or changes in the financial support of the center.
FY2122.Q118: Expanded partnerships will increase research and outreach opportunities.
